context: <b6_0>The first geological map of the U.S<b6_0/>. was produced <b5_0>in <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b10_0>1809<b10_0/><b5_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> by <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>William Maclure<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. In <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b13_0>1807<b13_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, Maclure <b9_0>commenced the self-imposed task of making a geological survey of the United States<b9_0/>. Almost every state in the Union was traversed and mapped by him, <b7_0>the Allegheny Mountains<b7_0/> being crossed and recrossed some <b11_0>50 times<b11_0/>. The results of his unaided labours were submitted to <a3_0>the <a3_1><a3_2>American Philosophical Society<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> in a memoir entitled <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b8_0>Observations on the Geology of the United States<a4_2/> explanatory of a Geological Map<b8_0/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, and published in <b12_0>the Society's Transactions<b12_0/>, together with the nation's first geological map. This antedates William Smith's geological map of England by <b14_0>six years<b14_0/>, although it was constructed using a different classification of rocks.
